thread.title: SA woman plans to open support service for displaced Aboriginal youth
thread.title_full: SA woman plans to open support service for displaced Aboriginal youth

author: Sowaibah Hanifie
title: SA woman plans to open support service for displaced Aboriginal youth
text:
By Sowaibah Hanifie Posted February 21, 2017 06:39:46 Map: Adelaide 5000 
A South Australian woman who was taken away from her Indigenous family as a child and moved between foster care homes hopes to establish a refuge for youth that embraces Aboriginal culture. 
Ngarrindjeri woman Deb Moyle said adversity during her younger years had shaped her hopes of improving support for other Aboriginal children in foster care. 
She said a third of Aboriginal children in care faced issues of self-confidence and saw their indigeneity as a deficit â€” something she wants to see changed. 
As a toddler in Adelaide Ms Moyle said she was put into kinship care and raised by her relatives when her own mother, just 16, had struggled to manage. 
She said growing up with an extended family enriched her knowledge of Aboriginal history and culture. 
"I was raised by unbelievably strong women," she recalled. 
But at the age of four, Ms Moyle said she was taken from a family she was familiar with and sent to Perth to live with her non-Aboriginal father. 
She said her time in Perth was frustrating as the people around her refused to acknowledge her Aboriginal roots and she was no longer surrounded by the comfort of an Indigenous community. 
At 14, Ms Moyle said she grew the confidence to see a welfare agency in Perth and demanded they investigate abuse she was facing in her father's care and she be returned to her mother. 'I was being punished for speaking up' 
She explained, instead of supporting her and her impoverished family reconnecting, the agency put her into a foster home. 
"I was being punished for speaking up," she said. Photo: Deb Moyle was taken away from Aboriginal relatives when she was just four years old. (Supplied: Deb Moyle) 
"They would say 'you're fair skinned, you don't have to go back there, you can move forward'." 
Ms Moyle said after two years of being moved from one home to another, it took intervention by members of Parliament before she was eventually returned to her mother and reunited with her siblings and other relatives. 
"Coming home to a unit filled with cousins, aunts and uncles was a culture shock, but it was a place I knew I needed to be," she said. 
"I now had an identity. I am a Ngarrindjeri. I am a member of the Ngarrindjeri nation. That immediately connected me to family. I have all this belonging and acceptance." 
Ms Moyle, now 50 with three daughters of her own, has worked her way up to become the most senior staff member in Aboriginal early childhood services. 
She is dedicating her efforts to help her community break out of what she said could be a cycle of poverty, teenage pregnancies and sometimes abuse. Aunties House aimed at reducing foster care trauma 
Speaking from her own experiences, she said it was difficult for her to "unlearn" the behaviours and attitudes that came with a disadvantaged childhood and this is what many Indigenous families struggled with. Photo: Deb Moyle was already a teenager before she was reunited with her mother and other Aboriginal relatives. (Supplied: Deb Moyle) 
"We could hear the stories, we know the damage. Children do not have guidance or the ability to come back to their community like me and be welcome with open arms and be strengthened by cultural knowledge," she said. 
Now, Ms Moyle along with her daughters and three other Aboriginal community members, plans to set up a support service they will call Aunties House, offering temporary accommodation for young Aboriginal children who need family support. 
She explained her aim behind Aunties House is to reduce the trauma experienced by children in foster care by surrounding them with familiar Aboriginal faces and ensuring they are guided by and remain connected to their families and culture. 
"We have to keep ourselves grounded with culture. Where will those children learn to not carry that baggage? How do they learn to think about themselves differently?" she said. 
"We have to remind Aboriginal people that our culture is our strength." 
She said Aunties House, which she anticipates will begin official plans within the next two years, will be another step to breaking the cycle of trauma experience by the many Indigenous children in foster care so they have the ability to reach their potential and not be held back by their past experiences.
